filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of forty-three pencil drawings produced by Blake during his first decade as an independent artist, 1779-1790. Drawing lies at the core of Blake's life as an artist. Pencil was his preferred medium for sketching—more flexible, less expensive, and more easily corrected than pen and ink or chalk. Preliminary work with the pencil preceded more finished work, either as separate sketches for prints and paintings or as drawings underlying water colors. Blake's nineteenth-century writings on the arts testify to his conviction that drawing was fundamental to all pictorial expression: "The distinction that is made in modern times between a Painting and a Drawing proceeds from ignorance of art. The merit of a Picture is the same as the merit of a Drawing" (*A Descriptive Catalogue*, Erdman page 549); "Let a Man who has made a Drawing go on & on & he will produce a Picture or Painting but if he chooses to leave off before he has spoild it he will Do a Better Thing[.]" (*Public Address*, Erdman page 576); "Painting is Drawing on Canvas & Engraving is Drawing on Copper & Nothing Else…& he who Draws best must be the best Artist…." (*Public Address*, Erdman page 582); "Dear Sir, excuse my enthusiasm or rather madness, for I am really drunk with intellectual vision whenever I take a pencil or graver into my hand…." (letter to William Hayley, 1804, Erdman page 757).
Blake no doubt executed a great many more pencil drawings than those extant today. Sketches were not intended for exhibition or sale; most were probably discarded, while others may have been retained only because of more developed compositions on the other side of the leaves. Even the slightest and least aesthetically ambitious drawings offer insights into the origins and earliest realizations of Blake’s designs. These first thoughts on paper often tell us more about Blake’s habits of mind, when joined by eye and hand, than more finished works. Sketches are “the first fruits of [Blake’s] imagination,” as Geoffrey Keynes states in the introduction to his *Pencil Drawings of William Blake* (1927).
The forty-three pencil drawings presented here, produced in Blake’s first decade as an independent artist, show his early debt to academic standards of precise copying and to the neoclassical emphasis on outline. The first four works may have been drawn while Blake was a student in the Royal Academy schools. Other sketches are preliminaries for some of Blake’s most important designs. Among these are the *Study for “Glad Day”, or “Albion Rose”* (Object 6), Blake’s iconic vision of the human form divine in energetic pose, and three sketches (Objects 34-36) for illustrations to *Tiriel*, the only group of finished drawings Blake composed for one of his own poems. Several sketches are early efforts at picturing events in the Bible, Blake’s main inspiration for designs throughout his life. This biblical cluster includes *The Resurrection of the Dead* (Object 10), *Samuel Presenting Saul to the People* (Object 15), and *Job’s Wife and Other Sketches* (Object 31). Other studies, such as *Ugolino in Prison* and its verso (Objects 21-22), reveal the beginnings of subjects also of lifelong interest for Blake. Only a few drawings for Blake’s illuminated books have survived, but studies such as *Sketches for “The Book of Thel”* and *A Standing and a Recumbent Figure* (Objects 37-39) offer fascinating glimpses into Blake’s methods of graphic production and revision.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

provenance.name: Victoria and Albert Museum
provenance.note: Inherited by Blake's wife Catherine at his death in 1827; acquired by Frederick Tatham, probably at Catherine Blake's death in 1831; sold Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, possibly lot 200 or 201 with 33 other works (2s. or 3s. to the dealer Francis Harvey) or lot 160 with four other works (9s. to George A. Smith); Smith by 1876, sold Christie's, 10 July 1880, in lot 121 or 122 (each lot bought by the dealer E. Parsons for 3s.); sold by Parsons to the Victoria and Albert Museum in 1881.

objnote.p: The pen and ink inscription below the design is attributed to Frederick Tatham in Butlin 207. The inscription lower right, "8763.B," is the Victoria and Albert Museum accession number written by a curator, probably c. 1881. See also the verso of this leaf, *Head of a Man and Small Head of Ugolino*, Butlin 207 verso. This recto pencil sketch is closely related to a monochrome wash drawing of approximately the same date, *Ugolino: "Does Thy God, O Priest, Take Such Vengeance as This?"*, Butlin 208. Blake executed several similar designs based on the subject of Ugolino in prison with his sons and grandsons, including a pencil sketch in his Notebook, Butlin 201.59; *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley plate 14; *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley plate 14; *The Marriage of Heaven and Hell*, Bentley plate 16; *Ugolino and His Sons in Prison* among the Dante water colors, Butlin 812.68; and the tempera painting, *Count Ugolino and His Sons in Prison*, Butlin 805. The present sketch is not a direct preliminary drawing for any of these later works.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a rectangular composition positioned against the right margin of the leaf, five figures sit in what appears to be the dark interior space of a prison. The central figure is Ugolino, a gowned male with curly hair standing on end and a beard. He sits cross-legged facing forward. His arms are at his sides. His facial expression suggests fear, despair, or madness. The other figures are his sons and grandsons. The rightmost figure, a nude male with long hair, sits or leans against a wall facing left with left arm by his side, hand clenched in a fist. His extended legs touch those of his companion at far left; his left ankle may be shackled. He turns his head up in a gesture that suggests despair. The second figure from the right sits with legs drawn up facing forward against the rear wall. He has long hair and may wear a gown. With arms by his sides, he turns his head up and to the left, perhaps to look toward the central figure. The second figure from the left, a nude(?) male with long hair, sits with legs drawn up facing forward and looking right, likely toward the central figure. His right arm is by his side with hand braced on the ground. The fifth and leftmost figure sits or leans against a wall facing right with head turned down and eye closed. He may wear a gown. His right arm is visible by his side with open palm braced on the ground, and his extended legs touch those of his companion at far right. Behind the central figure, several horizontal lines suggest a heavy, barred door in this prison. The diagonal shading of the interior walls indicates the darkness of the space.

component.illusobjdesc: In a rectangular composition positioned against the right margin of the leaf, five figures sit in what appears to be the dark interior space of a prison. The central figure is Ugolino, a gowned male with curly hair standing on end and a beard. He sits cross-legged facing forward. His arms are at his sides. His facial expression suggests fear, despair, or madness.

The rightmost figure, a nude male with long hair, sits or leans against a wall facing left with left arm by his side, hand clenched in a fist on the ground. His extended, slightly bent legs touch those of his companion at far left; his left ankle may be shackled. He turns his head up in a gesture that suggests despair. He is one of the sons or grandsons of Ugolino who is imprisoned with his family.
The rightmost figure may wear a shackle around his left ankle.

The second figure from the right sits with legs drawn up facing forward against the rear wall. He has long hair and appears to wear a gown. With arms by his sides, he turns his head up and to the left, perhaps to look toward the central figure. He is one of the sons or grandsons of Ugolino who is imprisoned with his family.

The second figure from the left, a nude(?) male with long hair, sits with legs drawn up facing forward and looking right, likely toward the central figure. His right arm is by his side with hand braced on the ground. He is one of the sons or grandsons of Ugolino who is imprisoned with his family.

The fifth and leftmost figure sits or leans against a wall facing right with head turned down and eye closed. He may wear a gown. His right arm is visible by his side with open palm on the ground, and his extended legs touch those of his companion at far right. His posture suggests despair. He is one of the sons or grandsons of Ugolino who is imprisoned with his family.

Behind the central figure, several horizontal lines suggest a heavy, barred door. The diagonal shading of the interior walls indicates the darkness of the space. The identification of these figures as Ugolino and his sons and grandsons indicates the space is a prison cell.
